title: U.S. stock futures slump as 10-year yield tops 1.80%
text:
A blockbuster tech deal was also in the spotlight, after Microsoft Corp. MSFT said it had reached an agreement to acquire Activision Blizzard Inc. ATVI in an all-cash deal valued at $68.7 billion.

What's happening

Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average YM00 were down 306 points, or 0.9%, at 35,490.

S&P 500 futures ES00 declined 46.50 points, or 1%, to 4,608.25.

Nasdaq-100 futures NQ00 dropped 236.75 points, or 1.5%, to 15363.

Last week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, S&P 500 SPX and Nasdaq Composite COMP each lost ground, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq now down 5% for the year.

What's driving markets

The big move in financial markets Tuesday was in bonds, as the yield on the 10-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 4 basis points to 1.83%, its highest since January 2020.

Yields on the 2-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD02Y, which are more sensitive to Fed policy expectations, shot up 9 basis points, rising above 1% for the first time since February 2020.

The 200-day moving average in Nasdaq-100 sits around 14,979, noted Peter Garnry, head of equity strategy at Saxo Bank.

“European and U.S. equity futures are flashing red amid a jump in Treasury yields, as investors brace for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates four times this year to tame inflation,” said Lukman Otunuga, senior research analyst at FXTM.

The week will feature quarterly reports from 35 companies in the S&P 500 index.  Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS on Tuesday said its fourth-quarter profit fell 13%, missing Wall Street estimates, in a choppy quarter for the Wall Street firm. Shares of Goldman Sachs fell 3.5% in premarket trades. 

Crude-oil prices CL.1 rose on Middle East unrest, as Houthi rebels launched a drone attack on a key oil facility in Abu Dhabi. The United Arab Emirates is OPEC's third-largest producer.

Which companies are in focus?

In its biggest ever acquisition, MicrosoftMSFTsaid it would pay $95 per ActivisionATVI share to create the world's third-biggest gaming company measured by revenue, behind Tencent and Sony. Microsoft shares fell 1.6%, while Activision surged nearly 38%.

Goldman Sachs Group GS fourth-quarter net earnings fell 13% to $3.81 billion or $10.81 a share. Revenue at the investment bank increased by 8% to $12.64 billion from $11.74 billion in the year-ago quarter. The investment bank missed the target of $11.77 a share in a survey of analysts by FactSet, but beat the revenue target of $12.04 billion. Shares of the Dow component were down by more than 4% in premarket action.

Shares of Plexus Corp.PLXS were lower after the electronic manufacturing services company warned that it will miss fiscal first-quarter profit and revenue guidance provided in October because of “unanticipated” supply chain challenges that worsened in the finals weeks of the quarter.
